bioghist.p: The Monte Carlo Integration Computer (MCIC) is a special purpose digital computer that utilizes the Monte Carlo integration method for simulating dynamic equilibrium and rate processes. The computer was designed for instructional purposes to allow chemistry students to simulate these processes at both the macroscopic (concentration of species) and microscopic (atomic and molecular) levels. The MCIC was originally developed in 1970-72 through a dissertation study at Temple University by Dean A. Wood under the direction of Frank X. Sutman.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of Dean Wood's 1971 Temple University doctoral thesis, entitled "The Monte Carlo Integration Computer as an Instructional Model for the Simulation of Equilibrium and Kinetic Chemical Processes: The Development and Evaluation of a Teaching Aid," and a binder entitled "Monte Carlo Integration Computer: Data collection and graphical dispay of concentration vs. time relationships for various rate and equilibrium processes as simulated by the Monte Carlo Integration Computer."

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
